text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
IRM 25.5.3.1, revised title and added content to comply with the Internal Management Documents System, Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) internal control requirements.

IRM 25.5.3.2(1)(c), moved paragraph 14 as part of paragraph 1 to be at the top of the list of serving a summons. In addition, added registered agent as an example of who can be served a summons on behalf of the corporation.

IRM 25.5.3.2(9), added guidance to include Part E for a designated or related summons. In the Note, included guidance to send notice copies to the noticee’s authorized representative(s), and added a note stating a return receipt is not required.
IRM 25.5.3.2(17), added information on the Certiﬁcate of Service and guidance for ﬁeld collection employees to use ICS to document service of the summons and how notice was given.
25.5.3.2(19), provided who to contact when a third party is willing to sign a waiver of service.
IRM 25.5.3.2.5, added new section, Summons Procedures During Natural Disasters.
IRM 25.5.3.3.1(1)c), added guidance regarding written approval attached to the designated
IRM 25.5.3.3.3.2(3), added language regarding prior reasonable requests made for the records requested in the designated summons.
IRM 25.5.3.3.4(2), clariﬁed that when a summons has been referred for enforcement, all communications with the taxpayer must be approved by the Department of Justice.
IRM 25.5.3.3.10(2)b), clariﬁed what to add to the memorandum regarding reasonable requests made for the records requested.
IRM 25.5.3.3.10(2)d), added guidance to obtain pre-review by Procedure and Administration.
25.5.3.4(7), removed link to the nearest IRS office since the link lists the nearest Taxpayer Center.
IRM 25.5.3.5(6), replaced IRM citation with link to the IT Virtual Library.
IRM 25.5.3.6.2.2, replaced storage device with PSD (portable storage device) and updated link to the Summons Knowledge Base site for instructions for saving electronic records.
Throughout this IRM, replaced “examiner” with “IRS employee” since this IRM is used by all IRS employees authorized to issue a summons. Also, replaced “the Service” with “the IRS.”

) Audience: All employees authorized to issue or approve a summons. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Collection Policy. (
) Program Owner: Collection Policy Headquarters, an organization within the Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE) division. (
) Primary Stakeholders: Employees who require testimony or the production records. (

) Program Goals: There are times when the IRS must compel a taxpayer or third-party to provide records or testimony through the use of a summons. Internal Revenue Code provides the IRS with summons authority, and there a mechanism to enforce compliance with summonses. By following the guidance in this IRM section, employees will be able to prepare and issue a summons in compliance with law and procedure, so that it is enforceable (if required) and results in the production of the necessary records and/or testimony. (
) Procedures for the preparation of a summons can be found in IRM

, Summons, Preparation. This section provides information and the proper cedures for: • Service of Summons • Designated Summons • Time and Place of Examination Set by Summons • Records on Encrypted Storage Media • Electronic Summons Processes (

The approval is evidenced by supervisor’s signature on the summons, or by a statement on the summons, signed by the issuing officer, that he or she had prior authorization to issue summons and stating the name and title of the authorizing official and date authorization. (

) In general, the IRS should issue summonses only when the information is already in the IRS’s possession, and the taxpayer (or other witness) will not produce the desired records or other information voluntarily. A summons is speciﬁc to each case. There are no program reports that track summonses third-party witnesses. (

, Financial Records Summons, Part A. Part A of the forms should be: a. Handed to the person to whom it is directed (preferred method of service); or b. Left at his or her last and usual place of abode by leaving it with a person who is of suitable age and discretion, with instructions that the summons be given to the summoned individual, or by affixing the summons to the front door of the last and usual place of abode by a means that will not mar the ﬁnish. The last and usual place of abode is where the person actually lives. It differs from a “last known address.” If the summoned person establishes that the service address was not last and usual place of abode, the defective service could make the summons unenforceable. c. A summons may be issued to a corporation for the production of corporate records. If the summons is directed to the custodian of it must be personally served on the custodian. If the summons is solely to the corporation, it must be personally served on a corporate officer or a person authorized to accept service of the summons on behalf of the corporation, such as a registered agent. Although IRC §

provides that a summons may be served by leaving it at the summoned person’s “last and usual place of abode,” this rule does not apply when a corporation is the summoned party because a corporation has no abode. Consequently, do not serve a summons on a corporation by leaving it at the custodian’s or the authorized person’s place of They are not the summoned corporation; they merely represent that entity. Note: A summons should not be prepared in the presence of the taxpayer. This action might encourage the taxpayer to become deﬁant and non-compliant. (

) Serve a summons issued to a third-party recordkeeper by registered or certiﬁed mail (preferred method of service), or personally deliver it to the person to whom it is directed. See IRM

, Third-Party Recordkeeper, for an explanation of third-party recordkeepers. Mail the summons to the last known address of the recordkeeper and document the case ﬁle by recording the method of service. The summons can be faxed or transmitted if the third-party signed a waiver authorizing service of the summons by fax electronic transmission. See paragraph (
) below. (

) If a witness requests that he or she be served with a summons as evidence his or her legal duty to produce records, testify, or provide handwriting analysis, and indicates he or she will voluntarily comply, issue the summons for that purpose. This is commonly referred to as a “friendly summons.” A friendly summons remains subject to IRC §
notice requirements, and for summonses requiring notice, the restriction on the inspection of records obtained under §

(d) will apply. However, do not follow this procedure a John Doe summons because such a summons can only be served after approval by a federal district court judge. Serving a John Doe summons without court approval violates the statute and may jeopardize the investiga- tion. (

) If information requested by a summons is later determined to be compliance with the summons may be waived by the issuing official, provided the summons is not the subject of litigation. If the summons is the subject of litigation, concurrence of the Counsel office handling the litigation must be obtained before compliance may be waived. (
) Witness fees and payments for mileage may be made to all summoned witnesses, whether a third-party witness, the taxpayer, or an officer or employee of the taxpayer. (Refer to IRM
, Claims for Witness Fees and Travel Expenses. Use Standard Form (SF)
, Claims for Witness At- tendance Fees, Travel and Miscellaneous Expenses, for this purpose.) (
) The Secretary may reimburse costs that are reasonably necessary and incurred in searching for, reproducing, or transporting records. However, IRC
(b) limits the summoned witnesses that are eligible for reimbursement of costs. IRC §
) excludes from eligibility third parties summoned to produce records in which the taxpayer has a proprietary interest. IRC §

) excludes from eligibility the taxpayer or the taxpayer’s officer, employee, agent, accountant, or attorney who was acting in that capacity the summons was served. If the person summoned is a third party entitled to reimbursement, he or she will be given the notice explaining the payment cedures (Part B of the summons forms); otherwise, discard Part B. See IRM
, Fees and Costs for Summoned Witnesses, for further information. (

Serving a third party summons is a third-party contact, which must generally, examination or collection cases, be preceded by advance notice from the IRS to the taxpayer that the IRS intends to contact third parties. In most cases between 2005 and the enactment of section 1206 of the Taxpayer First Act of 2019, P.L. 116-25, on July 1, 2019, the IRS addressed the advance third party contact notice requirement by providing the taxpayer with Pub 1, Your Rights as a Taxpayer. After August 15, 2019, the effective date of section 1206 of the Taxpayer First Act of 2019, an IRS examination or collection employee, jeopardy circumstances, must now provide the taxpayer with a new general advance notice at least 45 days before a third-party contact. This new general advance notice must inform the taxpayer that the IRS intends to make third-
party contacts within a speciﬁed time period not to exceed one year. Such advance notice of third-party contacts may be renewed by the IRS again by notice given
days in advance of the new speciﬁed period in which the IRS continues to intend to make third-party contacts. (

) When investigating the liability of a husband and wife who ﬁled a joint serve a separate summons on each spouse if it is necessary to obtain or testimony from both spouses. However, if only one spouse has custody or control of all of the records that may be relevant to the investigation, or if the IRS needs the testimony of only one spouse, serve only the spouse from whom the records or testimony is sought. Note: These summonses are treated by the IRS as third-party summonses to which the notice requirement of IRC §
(a) applies. If only one spouse summoned, the other spouse should be given notice under IRC §

(a) a person identiﬁed in the summons. Even when both spouses are summoned (by issuing and serving separate summonses), each spouse should be given notice of the other spouse’s summons. This procedure preserves each spouse’s opportunity to move to quash the summons on his or her spouse. See IRM
, Summons Served to Examine Married Person’s Joint Return. (

) When issuing a summons to a person in his or her capacity as trustee, receiver, custodian, corporate or public official, the person’s title or position the name of the entity should be added. For example, a summons for the testimony of a corporate president would read, “Mr. S, as president of XYZ Corporation.” (

) Any copy of a summons given to the person summoned should contain the following statement of attestation: “I hereby certify that I have examined and compared this copy of the summons with the original and that it is a true correct copy of the original.” (
) The back of the original summons must have a statement that the copy contained the required attestation. (

) After the summons has been served, complete the Certiﬁcate of Service on second page of the original summons and include the signature of the employee who served the summons. The Certiﬁcate of Service provides of the actual service of the summons. The Certiﬁcate of Service signed by person serving the summons is evidence of the facts it states during a of an application for enforcement of the summons. Field Collection will use Integrated Collection System (ICS) to document the service of the summons and how notice was given. See IRM
, Proper Service IRC §

) Place the summons form marked “Original” in the administrative ﬁle in the office of the issuing division for use in enforcement litigation. Note: If the summoned party fails to comply with the requirements of the summons, see IRM
, Enforcement of Summons, for enforcement cedures. (

) A summoned witness may waive proper service of the summons by signing waiver. The waiver should be in writing and the IRS should obtain the waiver from the witness in advance of serving the summons. The waiver can authorize service of the summons by certiﬁed mail, by fax, or by electronic transmission. Send an email to *SBSE E-Summons Decryption Team when Internal Revenue Manual

) To serve a summons in another area: • Collection should issue an Other Investigation (OI) — Summons via ICS for service of the summons in the receiving area. • Exam and Tax Exempt & Government Entities should use Form

, Collateral Examination, to send the summons to the other area to request that it be served. Refer to Collateral Examinations in IRM General Examining Procedures for additional information. • Criminal Investigation should prepare a collateral request for this purpose. (

) The initiating area should prepare the summons for issuance. The receiving area will complete the spaces on the summons indicating the name, and telephone number of the IRS employee before whom the summoned is required to appear, as well as the place and time for appearance. (
) Collection employees should contact Advisory for guidance on serving a summons on an individual or entity located outside of the United States. (
) Coordination and cooperation are necessary between the examining office another area. a. When conducting an IRC §

examination, it may be necessary to summon a person living or doing business in another area. If so, obtain approval to issue the summons from the Area Director for the area in which the examination is taking place. b. If the summons crosses area lines, the originating area will forward the summons to the area requested to cooperate. c. The examining office will provide a completed summons (if possible), a memorandum explaining the need for the information, and the assis- tance needed from the cooperating office. d. The examining office has the basic authority and responsibility for the summons and for its enforcement. The cooperating office acts as an agent of the examining office. e. Forward judicial enforcement requests to Associate Area Counsel the examining office is located. (
) In certain circumstances, documents related to foreign accounts or entities can be obtained by summons. See IRM

, Foreign Based Books and Records. The United States also has tax treaties and tax information exchange agreements with a number of countries pursuant to which foreign- based records can be obtained. ) The IRS can obtain information regarding entities and persons in the U.S. tories of American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Issued in Islands, Guam, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Prior to issuing summons; however, the IRS must generally notify the tax department of territories. This notiﬁcation must be made through the LB&I U.S. Territories Program.. (

) The United States has entered into tax coordination and tax agreements with each of the territories. ) There are two types of electronic summons processes. • One method is for the IRS employee to both serve the summons and later retrieve the records. The IRS employee, with the consent of the witness, serves the summons by uploading the summons to the elec- tronic portal. The third party notiﬁes the IRS employee by email when the records are ready for retrieval. The IRS employee returns to the electronic portal to retrieve the records. This process is a two-way mission process. • The second method is to use an electronic summons process to only retrieve records. The summons is served in the normal manner (e.g. hand delivery, certiﬁed mail, or fax). The third party notiﬁes the IRS employee by email when the records are ready for retrieval. The IRS employee retrieves the records from the electronic portal. This process is a one-way transmission process. (

) The employee’s email address is required to use electronic summons processes. Employees can provide the email address on the face of the summons, or provide the email address on a cover letter. The third party notiﬁcation by email when the records are ready. The third party will call the IRS employee if the email address is not provided on the summons or on a cover letter. (
